item.title: Monads: Scala vs. Clojure
item.description:
This summary follows from the magnificent talk by Juan Manuel Serrano Hidalgo as part of the CodeMotion 2016 in Madrid, Spain, available on Youtube.

Juan Manuel not only masterfully gives the fundamental idea of monads in Scala, but it does so in the finniest and most enjoyable way possible.

In this article I will build upon his constructs, filling in the empty blanks left in the talk. Although recommended, it is not necessary for you to watch the talk. It is, of course, recommended (although it is in Spanish).

Assume a software system composed of an interface, implementations of that interface, a program build on top of instances of that interface which is finally composed with the implementation in a configuration.

A very easy example consists of an echo program, which reads from an input and writes to an output. Easy enough right?

class IO {
   read () : String = ""
   write (msg : String)
}

def echo (io : IO) : Unit = {
   var msg : String = io.read
   io.write(msg)
}

Now, requisites change and we need to update our program to accommodate more use cases. Imagine that we no longer must use a unique synchronous IO module but also an asynchronous one. For this asynchronous interface, the echo program must be rewritten.

class IO {
   read () : Future(String) = ""
   write (msg : String)
}

def echo (io : IO) : Unit = {
   val msg: Future[String] = AsyncIO.read
   msg onComplete {
      case Success(strMsg) => io.write(strMsg)
      case Failure(t) => println ("error")
   }
}

Notice that we needed to change the implementation of our Echo program.

A natural question to ask ourselves is whether there is a way of using both, or any number of interfaces for that matter, without needing to modify our program. This is actually what monads solve, acting as adaptors of types so that a program can accept multiple interfaces at no extra cost. Of course, the trade off here is grater complexity and learning curve for the programmer.

Having this in mind, we set up to build a program that never changes no matter the interfaces it uses.

We can use something like adaptor objects that take care of the possible types that can occur in the interfaces of the program, given that we keep the interfaces' inputs intact.

Let's begin by formally specifying an IO interface that can accommodate several types of outputs and always accepts the same input parameters, i.e., none for read and String for write.

trait IO[P[_]] {
  def read(): P[String]
  def write(msg: String): P[Unit]
}

type Id[T] = T

object SyncIO extends IO[Id] {
  override def read(): String = "Sync!"
  override def write(msg: String): Unit = identity(msg)
}

object AsyncIO extends IO[Future] {
  override def read(): Future[String] = Future("Async!")
  override def write(msg: String): Future[Unit] = Future{ print(msg)}
}

We now write the new version of the program, that will use these adaptors, for each sentence that uses the IO interface. This adaptors are our monads:

def echo[P[_]](io: IO[P], m: Monad[P])(): P[String] = {
  m.bind(io.read(), { msg: String =>
    m.bind(io.write(msg), {_: Unit =>
      m.identity("Out message is: " + msg)})})
}

we see that, instead of simply using a classic statement to evaluate the interface instance and assign a value just to go on to the next instruction in an imperative way, we now evaluate the interface and put the value, whatever the interface returns as the output, into the first argument of a bind function. The second argument is a function that always accepts a String. identity just returns the monad containing a String. Why do we do this? If you pay attention, this was a sequence of instructions, which is what monads are. Let's disect the Monad interface and implementations.

We have the generic interface and two implementations that cover our two types of IO.

trait Monad[P[_]] {
  def bind[A,B](p: P[A], f: A => P[B]): P[B]
  def identity[A](x: A): P[A]
}

val monadId: Monad[Id] = new Monad[Id] {
  override def bind[A, B](p: Id[A], f: (A) => Id[B]): Id[B] = f(p)
  override def identity[A](x: A): Id[A] = x
}

val monadFuture: Monad[Future] = new Monad[Future] {
  override def bind[A, B](p: Future[A], f: (A) => Future[B]): Future[B] = p.flatMap(f)
  override def identity[A](x: A): Future[A] = Future(x)
}

The identity monad monadId does not do much. Its bind function just evaluates the function in the second argument with the first argument as the parameter value. The asynchronous monad asyncMonad is more elaborated. It evaluates to the flatMap of Future, itself being a monad. Yes, flatMap is the convention in Scala for bind in the academic literature. So it just passes f to the Future monad.

So going back to the echo program, the first step was to read a value from the IO object, which the monad then passes on to the lambda msg: String => m.bind(io.write(msg), ... i.e., it is binding the result of read to the symbol msg. The second use of the monad takes the return of write and binds it to nothing _, because it will never be used, and then evaluates the body to a screen text print.

The composition of the program, that can take place in a configuration or main program, for each case, is:

def syncEcho: () => String = echo[Id](SyncIO, monadId)
def asyncEcho: () => Future[String] = echo[Future](AsyncIO, monadFuture)

We can use the synchronous version as:

syncEcho()

And the asynchronous one:

val eventualString: Future[String] = asyncEcho()
Await.ready(eventualString, Duration.create(100, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)).value.get.get

Now, how do we port this to Clojure? In Clojure we don't have types, but we do have futures so we are kind of in a grey area that has been covered by a number of articles.

As in Scala, we first define our object interface versions, which in Clojure are pure functions

Synchronous:

(defn io-sync-read []
  "sync!")

(defn io-sync-write [msg]
  (println msg))

Asynchronous:

(defn io-async-read []
  (future "async!"))

(defn io-async-write [msg]
  (future (println msg)))

So, how are the Monads written in Clojure? We directly interpret what happens in Scala on each case. Also, notice that we do not need the version of pure in this particular case.

(defn mo-sync-bind [f v]
  (f v))

(defn mo-async-bind [f v]
  (future (f @v)))

We will use a closure for the program that accepts the chosen set of IO functions and the monad function.

(defn echo [[read write mbind]]
  (fn []
    (let [msg (read)
          _   (mbind write msg)]
      (mbind #(str "this was the message: " %) msg))))

We use the mbind as the adaptor to interpret what msg is and pass it on as an argument that write understands. Notice that the program is a let, which you will find in many places as the example of monad in Clojure, since in itself is a multiplicity of binds. The only thing missing here was types, pervasively hidden in Clojure but not absent. This fact is not surprising, since it is the nature we have been trying to uncover the while article about monads: They are the class of imperative programs!

As a final note, there is a pretty interesting Clojure library called Fluokitten that uses the monad concept of boxing in Clojure, though its practicality is limited due to the core language handling of nulls.

item.title: Elasticsearch and GIS
item.description:
We saw that MySQL comfortably deals with GIS data. Now it is the turn of Elasticsearch.

We will upload the geospatial information from a shapefile to Elasticsearch. Shapefiles are a standard in the GIS world, and are normally accompanied by other files, including a DBF file. This DBF file can be opened in Excel or Libreoffice, and it normally specifies region data, including names. For this example, we will use the Global Adminsitrative Area's Spain shapefile

I used my Hackintosh to do the whole thing, and the version maintained on Homebrew is too old to support the commands we need. So I needed to compile a new one and replace the sources from Homebrew with the official ones and then install them with the ```brew``` command.

You can get the sources using Subversion (as of the time of writing the latest tag was 2.1.1):

svn co https://svn.osgeo.org/gdal/tags/2.1.1

Then copy the sources to your previously installed Homebrew sources (search how to get sources with Hombrew, the package is gdal).

Once we've got the latest version in place, we issue the following command:

ogr2ogr -progress --config WRITE_MAPPING "esmap.json" -f "ElasticSearch" http://localhost:9200 es_peninsula.shp

The config value ```WRITE_MAPPING``` to write the map, it never produces the file, but it does produce the correct mapping in the index. The rest are Elasticsearch's URL and the shapefile.

We now check the existence of the index

curl -X GET 'http://localhost:9200/_cat/indices'

yellow open es_peninsula 5 1   54 0 4.4mb 4.4mb

And get the resulting mapping

curl -X GET 'http://localhost:9200/es_peninsula/_mapping'
{
  "es_peninsula": {
    "mappings": {
      "FeatureCollection": {
        "_meta": {
          "fid": "ogc_fid",
          "geomfields": {
            "geometry": "POLYGON"
          }
        },
        "properties": {
          "geometry": {
            "type": "geo_shape"
          },
          "ogc_fid": {
            "type": "long"
          },
          "properties": {
            "properties": {
              "CCA_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "CCN_2": {
                "type": "long"
              },
              "ENGTYPE_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "HASC_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "ID_0": {
                "type": "long"
              },
              "ID_1": {
                "type": "long"
              },
              "ID_2": {
                "type": "long"
              },
              "ISO": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "NAME_0": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "NAME_1": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "NAME_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "NL_NAME_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "TYPE_2": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "VARNAME_2": {
                "type": "string"
              }
            }
          },
          "type": {
            "type": "string"
          }
        }
      },
      "Feature": {
        "properties": {
          "query": {
            "properties": {
              "term": {
                "properties": {
                  "NAME_2": {
                    "type": "string"
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }

}

Notice the "geometry" property of type "geo_shape". This is the basic geographical type we use.

We now post a search on the type, and request all available data for the Madrid region.

curl -X POST 'http://localhost:9200/es_peninsula/FeatureCollection/_search' -d '{
    "query": {
        "match" : {
            "properties.NAME_1" : "Madrid"
        }

}'

{

Imagine the input query is inexact or inaccurate, and we are still interested in getting the information about the Madrid region. We can use a fuzzy search.

curl -X POST 'http://localhost:9200/es_peninsula/FeatureCollection/_search' -d '{
    "fields" : ["properties.NAME_1", "properties.NAME_2"],
    "query": {
        "match" : {
            "properties.NAME_1" : {
                "query" : "Mardid",
                "fuzziness" : 2
            }
        }
    }
}'

Were we have limited the output to the name fields of the administrative area to avoid the large output which would have resulted from getting Madrid's polygon shape.

          ],

            "Comunidad de Madrid"
          ]
        }
      }
    ]
  }
}

We could use the polygon shape information as input to another query as an enclosing polygon to retrieve items available in the database.

Now, the question remains: which is faster? MySQL or Elasticsearch? I might compare them if I find the time.

item.title: MySQL full text search: a simple example
item.description:
Following the previous post on MySQL GIS capabilities, this post is devoted to using MySQL as a text search engine like Apache Solr or Elasticsearch, but with no need for those systems.

Table creation

First, we define the table schema

USE `gis`;

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `deal`;

CREATE TABLE `deal` (
	`id` INT NOT NULL auto_increment,
    `titulo` TEXT NOT NULL,
    `desc` TEXT NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
    UNIQUE KEY `id`(`id`),
    FULLTEXT(`titulo`, `desc`)
) ENGINE=MyISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

With this, we have declared two text fields and a fulltext index including both.

Sample data insertion

Insert some values into the fields, there is nothing of significance here

INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Pregnant baby doll','A baby doll that is pregnant, the baby\'s baby is pregnant too');
INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Liquour from Malta', 'Delicious blend of fruity blueberry liquour. Alcoholic drink');
INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Scotch Whiskey', 'Fine whiskey from Scotland. The best in the world');
INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Toyota Yaris', 'Diesel affordable car');
INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Mercedes Class C4', 'Diesel car only for those who can afford it');
INSERT INTO `deal` (`titulo`, `desc`) VALUES('Wine El Yantar', 'Affordable alcoholic drink. Cheap red wine.');

Data querying

We now use a match against query in the following way

SELECT `titulo`, `desc` FROM `deal`
	WHERE MATCH(`titulo`, `desc`) AGAINST ('affordable') ;

In the following result, we notice that only the full word affordable has been searched, but that we obtain no result involving any type of variation such as the Mercedes row, which has the root afford.

+ ----------- + --------- +
| titulo      | desc      |
+ ----------- + --------- +
| Toyota Yaris | Diesel affordable car |
| Wine El Yantar | Affordable alcoholic drink. Cheap red wine. |
+ ----------- + --------- +
2 rows

The same will happen when querying afford

+ ----------- + --------- +
| titulo      | desc      |
+ ----------- + --------- +
| Mercedes Class C4 | Diesel car only for those who can afford it |
+ ----------- + --------- +
1 rows

NGram search

If we want to get result in a fashion similar to the use of Google (or other text search engines), the final step will be to use an NGram parser. We redefine our table schema like this:

USE `gis`;

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `deal`;

CREATE TABLE `deal` (
	`id` INT NOT NULL auto_increment,
    `titulo` TEXT NOT NULL,
    `desc` TEXT NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
    UNIQUE KEY `id`(`id`),
    FULLTEXT(`titulo`, `desc`) WITH PARSER ngram
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

This will only work with MySQL version 5.7.6 for tables using InnoDB.

This will give us the desired result when querying for subset of words.

item.title: MySQL GIS capabilities: query geographical locations simple example
item.description:
MySQL can be used as a GIS (Geographic Information System) database backend thanks to its spatial functions, which have been around since version 5.6 for MyISAM engine and since 5.7.5 for InnoDB engine.

Now, since InnoDB offers transactional capabilities too, i.e., a fully ACID-compliant DB engine. It is very interesting for a development in need of geographic information to be used alongside common business DB operations.

In this case, I will limit myself to using MyISAM for this example, since the only point is to show how we can use MySQL to retrieve data points from a query. The query itself could come from a reverse search by the Google Maps API (query by spatial features such as coordinates, distance or containing areas)

Creating the schema

Let's create a table called nodes with the following schema:

USE `gis`;

DROP TABLE `nodes`;

CREATE TABLE `nodes` (
  `id` bigint(20) DEFAULT NULL,
  `geom` geometry NOT NULL,
  `name` varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
  UNIQUE KEY `i_nodeids` (`id`),
  SPATIAL KEY `i_geomidx` (`geom`)
) ENGINE=MyISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

The only outstanding thing is the geometry related elements. We can spot the special geometry data type and the spatial key, which creates a spatial indexed. To do this, a special type of indexing is used for spatial data called R-tree (Region tree) indexing. This involves organizing the minimum bounding rectangle (MBR) of the spatial objects in a tree structure that is then used by the different spatial functions.

An R-tree index organizes the indexed nodes in a hierarchy where the nodes in the index represent the MBR of the objects in the node. The leaf nodes in the index contain references to the row that contain the data, just like a B+-tree index.

Inserting points

Let's insert some data into the table:

INSERT INTO `nodes` (`id`,`geom`,`name`) VALUES (1,ST_GeomFromText('POINT(108.875000 34.216020)'),'Point 1');
INSERT INTO `nodes` (`id`,`geom`,`name`) VALUES (2,ST_GeomFromText('POINT(109.569098 36.64635)'),'Point 2');
INSERT INTO `nodes` (`id`,`geom`,`name`) VALUES (3,ST_GeomFromText('POINT(109.550988 36.633384)'),'Point 3');
INSERT INTO `nodes` (`id`,`geom`,`name`) VALUES (4,ST_GeomFromText('POINT(109.472800 36.624116)'),'Point 4');
INSERT INTO `nodes` (`id`,`geom`,`name`) VALUES (5,ST_GeomFromText('POINT(109.487460 36.563614)'),'Point 5');

Notice the use of the construct Point. This is one of the possible GIS data types that can be used from MySQL.

Quering the database

Let us make a geometry to query data (notice that the last data point must be the same than the initial one, effectively closing the surface)

SET @g3 = ST_GeomFromText('Polygon((108 36.5,108 36.7,109.5 36.7,109.5 36.5,108 36.5))');

We can now query which data points in the database are related to the geometry:

SELECT `name`, st_x(`geom`) AS x,st_y(`geom`) AS y, contains(@g3,`geom`)>0 FROM `nodes`
  WHERE contains(@g3,`geom`)>0;

Notice that we are using contains, which checks whether the points fall within the minimum bounding rectangle (MBR) which encloses the box.

+ --------- + ------ + ------ + --------------------------- +
| name      | x      | y      | contains(@g3,`geom`)>0      |
+ --------- + ------ + ------ + --------------------------- +
| Point 1   | 1      | 1      | 1                           |
| Point 2   | 1      | 5      | 1                           |
| Point 3   | 5      | 1      | 1                           |
| Point 4   | 5      | 5      | 1                           |
+ --------- + ------ + ------ + --------------------------- +
4 rows

We get all four points but the area only encloses three of them. You can see our problem here in this illustration:

We can get points that don't belong to the queried region, but that only fall within their MBR, since the default version of the spatial functions use MBRs, and are equivalent to using the mbr-prefixed versions. In this case, the full name for contains is really mbrcontains.

To address this, a new set of functions was introduced as of 5.6 which are prefixed with st_.

Let's repeat the query using st_contains:

SELECT `name`, st_x(`geom`) AS x,st_y(`geom`) AS y, st_contains(@g3,`geom`)>0 FROM `nodes`
  WHERE st_contains(@g3,`geom`)>0;

which results in

+ --------- + ------ + ------ + ------------------------------ +
| name      | x      | y      | st_contains(@g3,`geom`)>0      |
+ --------- + ------ + ------ + ------------------------------ +
| Point 1   | 1      | 1      | 1                              |
| Point 2   | 1      | 5      | 1                              |
| Point 3   | 5      | 1      | 1                              |
+ --------- + ------ + ------ + ------------------------------ +

Comments

InnoDB is ligther and faster to query but it is not ACID-compliant. On the other hand, InnoDB also offers full-text search, which can cheaply provide us with a basic but fully-operative text search engine in the same table in case we need it. Nevertheless, we can combine MyISAM and InnoDB to get the best of bith worlds by using them in specific tables: One for GIS and one for text.

item.title: Interactive, high throughput, low turnaround development in the JVM: my setup
item.description:
From my former team lead at Erudine I learnt the value of low turnaround JVM code execution for high throughput, and productive interactive development.

What I mean by this is:

  • Running one and only one JVM almost all the time
  • Recompiling and reload your classes, hotswapping new versions for old ones.
  • Creating instances of your classes interactively using a REPL orinteractive console

This enables a very fast development lifecycle and lowers new libraries learning curves by interactively exploring them.

My setup

In my opinion, the best IDE for this task is IntelliJ IDEA. Not only it provides fast development by being heavily keyboard shortcut biased, but it also includes running configurations that can be adapted to any possible setup you might need.

In my case, I normally use Cursive with Clojure. But if I only need Java, a Scala REPL (the Scala plugin is totally free, albeit it lacks smoothness, especially on Windows) suffices.

I usually switch the Oracle VM to DCEVM, a JVM runtime that installs on top of it (or OpenJDK). Next, I get the Hotswap Agent, a Java agent that watches file changes (in this case bytecode class changes due to new compilations) and performs the hotswapping on the DCEVM. This agent must be used from the running configuration on IntelliJ (the Scala console running configuration).

If you want to install the DCEVEM as the alternative JVM in your JDK, you need to specifically use it from the command line, along with the use of the agent:

-XXaltjvm=dcevm -javaagent:PATH_TO_AGENT\hotswap-agent.jar

This must also be included in the running configuration from IntelliJ in the JVM parameters section.

Summary

  • Get IntelliJ IDEA
  • Get DCEVM
  • Get the Hotswap Agent
  • Add the Scala SDK to your Java project and create a runningconfiguration using the Hotswap agent and specifying the use ofthe Hotswap agent and, potentially, DCEVM as the altjvm.
  • Click on debug to start the Scala REPL with Hotswap capabilities

You can now create Java objects of any class on your classpath, including classes from your libraries or classes from your project. In the latter case, you can now change their code, recompile with Ctrl+F9, and you will be able to see a green box telling you the number of reloaded classes (you did something wrong otherwise and the setup is not complete).

You will need to accommodate a minimal Scala syntax such as val or var to create variables.

item.title: Oxidative stress: its causes, its consequences and its solution
item.description:
I used to get the flu twice a year in average, and many more common colds. Since I started taking chinese green tea and, later, other supplements, my cold and flu have gone away for good. This is nothing but a noticeable consequece mainly of oxidative stress.

Causes

The human body, and that of any other living creature, is essentially a water bag where a lot of organic chemical reactions happen. This reactions have a residue footprint which needs to be taken care of. This residue my be of the form of free electrons, which will be looking for a positively-charged molecule to bind to. Another harmful residue type is the so-called free radicals, which are incomplete molecules, or their combining heads, which are able to bind to other molecules in a chemical reaction in place of the intended molecule, since they share the combining part. The resulting molecule is not, however, the desired one.

If a molecule which itself needs to exist as it is in order to give raise to another chemical reaction is oxidized or a free radical happens to be in a location where a chemical reaction where the compatible molecule is intended to be used, this second reaction may not occur or, worse, it may fail to produce the intended result.

Another way of getting oxidative stress is through exogenous administration of toxins or other oxidants. These may come in the diet and become oxidizers once their are at a specific location within the human body.

Consequences

Since oxidizers prevent chemical reactions from obtaining the desired product, the harmful effect is two-fold:

  • Organic stores are depleted, since some material is wasted in a processwith an unwanted result
  • This unwanted product may end up being toxic for the surrounding tissue,itself preventing other processes from producing the intended result.

Oxidizers harm cell membranes, including neurons (which makes them one possible cause for Alzheimer's), they oxidize other molecules such as proteins, DNA, RNA, and so forth. Thus, we might not get enough proteins from DNA transcription, making us sick in a number of ways if we reach a threshold. Normal processes are hampered, including the ones needed for immunology, which weakens our defences against disease. If DNA is harmed beyond repair, a cancer might be born, and if natural cancer fighting mechanisms (apoptosis, for example) may not be enough to stop it, which happens if our immunologic system is weak.

Solution

Exercise is an excellent way of getting rid of toxins. However, a good diet contains many of the antioxidants needed for the everyday activity.

Green tea

The secret of green tea is its antioxidants. Green tea is high in cathechins and polyphenols, two types of antioxidant molecules, which means they reduce oxidative stress resulting from the normal biological activity of the body (and increased by dietary bad practice).

One of the catechins, EGCg (Epigallocatechin gallate), is known to be a powerful free radical scavenger, antioxidant, and NGF (Nerve Growth Factor) inducer/amplifier, which promotes the growth of neurons at any age and keeps our brain healthy.

Vitamin C

Vitamin C is the most common water-soluble antioxidant and one of the most studied. Vitamin C comes in several forms, having the Ascorbate radical in common (which means absence of scurvy). The most common form, ascorbic acid, is acidic, so that the stomach will have a limit in the amount it can tolerate before provoking burps and belly moves. Sodium ascorbate is a salt form which is gentler to the stomach. Studies show that the amount orally taken and the amount that is absorbed are not proportional, but follows some kind of logarithmic relationship $absorbed = log(taken)$. Also, much of it is destroyed in the stomach. For both the previous reasons, Vitamin C is best taken in small doses over the day.

Liposomal C

Liposomal C is Internet hype which is not liposomal at all. Liposomes are fatty capsules that go through the stomach, the intestine walls and the bloods and that fuse with cell walls, liberating their content within cells.

Liposomes are too expensive and complicated to be built with house equipment as the hype claims. What you can achieve with an ultrasound machine and lecithin is emulsified vitamin C, which means that it will bind to a both fat-water-soluble emulsifier (lecithin), making it more ready to be absorbed by the intestines. So, despite being a leap in what absorption has to do, they reach cells no easier than any other form of Vitamin C.

Vitamin E

Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant. Apart from its antioxidant activity, Vitamin E is an antiviral that kills the HPV (Human Papilomavirus), which affects the skin by growing strange artifacts, including warts. As a fat-soluble molecule, Vitamin E can be stored in the liver so consumption can be made at any time but excess can build up and reach toxic amounts.

Selenium

Selenium is a powerful antioxidant which also helps thyroid function and brain development. Selenium can take free electrons, relieving surrounding tissue.

Lutein and carothenoids

Lutein is the most common carothenoid in the brain and eyes. It has neuroprotective capabilities.

Other carothenoids are especially present in carrots and are excellent antioxidants.

item.title: Building a Machine Learning-based automated trading system
item.description:
There are many hedge funds and trading houses currently using automated algorithms to place directional bets on the market.

While they can access immensely more vast resources than us, the average Joe (namely: better and much larger datasets), they need to essentially fight the same kind of problem (if the fractal market theory holds): Statistical independence.

Let's lead some data from Yahoo Finance. Let's fetch the Apple Inc. data, get the EOD (adjusted close) price and compute the (absolute) returns.

import pandas.io.data as web
aapl = web.get_data_yahoo('AAPL', '1/1/2005', '1/1/2016')
aaplprice = aapl['Adj Close']
aaplreturns = aaplprice.diff()

Check that the correlation is about 0.004:

aaplreturns.corr(aaplreturns.shift(-1))

Now let us study the distribution of the returns. First, import everything

from pylab import plot, hist, scatter, show

If we observe financial data, any asset's returns will appear to have a Gaussian distribution. The following is a distribution of the returns, where we appreciate some Gaussianity, although the tails are just to heavy for the data to be Gaussian.

hist(aaplreturns.dropna(), bins=30)

Any pair of data for any timeframe will appear to have a uncorrelated bivariate Gaussian distribution. We can safely assume that any chain of data for any period $X_t, X_{t+1}, \ldots , X_{t+n}$ will be distributed as an uncorrelated multivariate Gaussian which, as we know, implies statistical independence between variables. A fact that prevents us from gaining any knowledge of the future by using the past, no matter what method we use, there are no patterns to learn. In the image below, we plot a day's returns against those of the following day. We can tell that the data is not multivariate Gaussian since the data far from the center are just too frequent.

scatter(aaplreturns, aaplreturns.shift(-1))

However, market data has been proven not to be normally distributed, but to follow a stable distribution with no second moment (see, for example, Mandelbrot's work). One can still expect that, despite normality not holding, correlation still implies independence, at least to an extent.

So that's a problem. We want to do a task that is fundamentally impossible: Learn patters that are valid for the future from statistically irrelevant information from the past.

But there is hope: if correlations are small and the data, not being Gaussian, invalidates the correlation-independence implication, then we might seek a transformation of the future that aggregates this correlation and that still is meaningful when trading. Now, I am currently investigating what profit this transformation can yield, but my intermediate results show a correlation of the predicted future as high as 0.35 for some assets, using only intra-asset information.

The prediction is a regression task in a high noise setting, so I used decision forests and avoided highly non-linear methods. I plan on stacking up regressors to capture inter-asset information. The output of this method will feed a Markowitz-style postfolio selection, though I need to work out the sparsity and integrity of the optimization problem. Based on the result, the account money needs to be allocated to assets, and this is a transportation-like task.

In the next post I will talk about data munging and data mining.

item.title: JFF: a reactive web application with reagent, re-frame and datascript
item.description:
Essensys, the last company I worked for in London, use to do something called Junk Food Friday, which, as you can guess, implies that each friday, one of us would order food for everybody else, be it pizza, burgers, Mexican, you name it. The process used to be a mess, with the organizer receiving emails with the requests, having an Excel sheet to organize him/herself, etc. That is why I developed the JFF app, which was an update from the coffee app (which was aimed at getting coffee from the local coffee shop, essentially the same use case).

I decided to give the new cool Clojure(Script) technologies a go and I was quite impressed (coming from working only with Reagent, Figwheel and a little bit of Datascript). Re-frame really adds value by providing a controller and a better model than just bare reagent atoms.

Since the web app shows all the updated content from the server, I figured out the communication system was the same than an chat system but, in this case, the message is the state change induced by any of the clients. So, the design is as follows:

  • Datascript database in both the server and the client. The client'sDB is a reflection of the state of the server DB.
  • core.async maintains a general channel, a client channel (per client)and a listening channel which taps the general channel and redistributesany message generated by any client to all of the clients. Messagesare valid Datascript EDN. The client channel is connected to a websocket.
  • When the Datascript EDN is received by the client, it is transacted intothe local in-browser Datascript database. Changes in the database arelinked to re-frame subscriptions via declarative query functions,whose change (upon DB change) generate data that triggers a reagentcomponent refresh.

Perhaps this is best seen as a diagram

Although you can see arrows in the previous diagrams, no specific calls are made to each of the components. In the client, whenever the user initiates a change, usually with the ```on-click``` handler of the web component, the re-frame handler generates the corresponding Datascript temporary transaction data according to the latest state (this means generating temporary IDs for the potentially new entitities), which will be a reflection of the server state.

That is sent via a core.async channel (ClojureScript version) which is attached to a websocket (Chord library, which directly returns a core.async channel).

On the server, there are three type of channels:

  • One websocket channel per client
  • One general channel
  • One channel tapping the general channel per client

The first receives transaction data from its client and sends it permanent transaction data once the server has transacted the data into its own DB. The general channel gets permanent data that has just transacted into the server's DB which is distributed to each of the tapping channels. When the program gets the data from the tapping channels, it writes it back to the client channel it is handling, as mentioned at the beginning of the paragraph.

The most important clojure function is the following

(defn ws-handler [{:keys [ws-channel] :as req} {:keys [chat-ch chat-mult]}]
  (let [tapped-ch (a/chan)
        conn (:conn @app-state)
        init-tx   (mapv (comp op-eav datom->vec) (d/datoms (d/db conn) :eavt))]
    (a/tap chat-mult tapped-ch)
    (println (format "Opened connection from %s."
                     (:remote-addr req)))
    (go
      (when (not-empty init-tx)
        (send! ws-channel init-tx))
      (loop []
        (a/alt!
          tapped-ch ([message] (if message
                                 (do
                                   (respond-to-tapped-ch ws-channel message)
                                   (recur))
                                 (do
                                   (println "NO msg")
                                   (a/close! ws-channel))))

          ws-channel ([ws-message] (if ws-message
                                     (do (respond-server-channel chat-ch ws-message)
                                         (recur))
                                     (do
                                       (println "Exiting")
                                       (a/untap chat-mult tapped-ch))))
          )))))

Where you can identify ws-channel as the client websocket channel, chat-ch (and its multiplexed version chat-multi) as the general channel and ```tapped-channel``` as the channel tapping the general channel.

Whenever ws-channel has a message, we transact it into the DB via the function respond-server-channel,

(defn respond-server-channel [chat-ch ws-message]
  (let [message (:message ws-message)
        conn    (:conn @app-state)
        tx-data (:datascript-tx message)
        tx-data (when tx-data
                  (:tx-data (d/transact! conn tx-data)))
        ]
    (if tx-data
      (do
        (spit session-file-name @conn)
        (send! chat-ch (mapv (comp op-eav datom->vec) tx-data)))
      (do
        (process-command message)
        (send! chat-ch message)))
    ))

This function will also put the resulting permanent transaction into the general channel. The tapping channels will pick this up and then send the permanent transactions to the clients via ws-channel. Notice that we create all of these channels upon client connection, except the general channel, which is created on server startup.

        chat-ch (a/chan)
        chat-mult (a/mult chat-ch)

At the client side we can divide the app into three sections: the model, the view and the controller. The view is seamlessly handled by reagent. The model and the controller are re-frame. The controller is made of handlers which are connected to the DOM components via the on-click callback, and that are of this form

(register-handler :pre-add-section
                  (fn [db [_ section-name]]
                    (let [server-ch (:server-ch db)
                          tx-data   [{:db/id -1 :section/name section-name}]]
                      (send-datascript-tx! server-ch tx-data)
                      )
                    db))

As we can see, it is the controller the one building the temporary transaction data (see the negative id) and send it to the server.

The model is made of subscriptions which contain queries for the local datascript DB. When we receive data from the websocket channel on the client, we insert it into the local, in-browser DB. The change on the DB triggers a change in the subscription DB query value.

(register-sub :post-user-names
              (fn [db _]
                (query->reaction db
                                 '[:find [?name ...]
                                   :where
                                   [_ :user/name ?name]
                                   ])))

This change, then, triggers a refresh in the reagent components (the view) that have subscribed to it, such as this one

(defn user-selection-component [user-name]
  (let [choice-names @(subscribe [:post-user-choices user-name])]
    [:li.list-group-item
     [:div
      user-name
      (vec
        (concat [:div]
                (for [choice-name choice-names]
                  [:div choice-name])))]]))

The source code is fully available on Github.

item.title: New blog using Cryogen
item.description:
Octopress was getting the worst out of me. It does not allow a natural git workflow and it is very difficult to manage in the long run. I sincerely believe Octopress is to blame for my inactivity in the past months.

Well, I have been looking for a replacement for a while and, since I am a Clojure enthusiast, what could then be better than a Clojure-written static web page generator?

Cryogen uses Leiningen and EDN config files for your setup. The automatic compiler, which listens to file changes, generates your pages which can then be refreshed into the browser. I need to investigate if I can automate the refreshing further.

It took me a while to figure out how to port the Mathjax equations. It looks like the Markdown parser like to mess up with the sub and super indices of Latex. You need to either use a space between the variable and the super index, as in x ^2, or escape the subindex with backslash.

What I don't like is that it is a little basic at the moment. Nevertheless, it fits my needs perfectly. Another drawback is that generating web pages is an expensive process that takes a lot of CPU and disk processing. You can notice this and, as a developer or blog author, this is not ideal. Anyhow, it is a good tool. Now I will be able to push my blog source to Bitbucket, which will live completely independent of the web page generator (unlike Octopress), and the generated pages to Github pages.

item.title: Clojure parallel thread flows: pth library
item.description:
I developed a new library that solves the problem of the need to disrupt a Clojure thread flow because two quantities need to be computed from the current value of the thread flow, for example, using the current value as the index to two arrays which need to be merged.

(use 'pth)

(let [map1 {:1 :a :2 :b :3 :c}
        map2 {:1 1 :2 2 :3 3}
        combine (partial apply interleave)
        into-map (partial apply array-map)
        ]
    (-> [:1 :2]
        (-<< (map map1)
             (map map2))
        combine
        into-map
        ))

Observe that in the second step of the thread, we compute two values without structurally breaking the flow or needing an overly complex construct such as

(#(do [(map map1 %) (map map2 %)]))

Do not worry about the utility functions combine and into map, I will create extra macros that are argument-first and argument-last, so that you will be completely free regarding which outer thread form you want to use, and then pick up the incoming value.

item.title: Max subsequence problem
item.description:
The following brainteaser is about finding the maximum-sum subsequence within a given sequence. We will solve this problem in Clojure, sice this will involve less pain than doing it in Java.

We need to decompose the sequence in parts, and a natural way of doing it is dividing it in halves, using a binary tree. For this purpose, we take the sequence at the current stage, divide it in two parts, and call the same function recursively for each half. The recursion-stopping criteria are the point when we find either two or only one element in the sequence (odd or even super sequence), at which point we return the information we need (we'll talk about this later on).

(defn best [myseq]
  (let [N (count myseq)]
    (case N
      1 nil
      2 nil
      (let [n (Math/round (double (/ N 2)))
            m (- N n)
            s1 (take n myseq)
            s2 (take-last m myseq)
            m1 (best s1)
            m2 (best s2)
            ]

        ))
    ))

This was the basic recursion skeleton. Now we need to return and process the interesting information about the sequence at each stage. We need the maximum-sum sub-sequence at each stage in the binary search, the discarded sequence at the left, and the discarded sequence at the right (both of which must be negative because they would otherwise increase the sum). For example, the sequence ```[-1 -1 3 4 -2]``` would produce a best subsequence ```[3 4]```, a discarded left sequence ```[-1 -1]``` and a discarded right sequence [-2]. Optionally and for the sake of performance, we also return the sums of these sequences, so that we don't need to recompute at the upper-levels (when returning from the call). The information retrieved from the lower levels is a map with this structure (using the previous example):

{:l -2 :sum 7 :r [-2] :sl [-1 -1] :seq [3 4] :sr [-2]}

where the first three keys are the sums, and the last three keys are the proper sequences. We now build the information according to the sequence we recieve as input. When there is only one element, it is easy to see that we need to return empty discarded sequences, and the input number as the best sequence. If we get two elements, we need to check whether both are positive, in which case, we return both as the best sequence (and empty discarded left and right sequences). Otherwise, get the maximum, return it as the best sequence, and return the other as either the left or right discarded sequence depending on whether it was the first or second in the sequence. Note, at this point, that the discarded sequences mean how large the penalization is to get to the best sequence for a given subsequence from the left or the right. In the recursion stage, when we have two subsequences, we need to check if the total sum of both best subsequences and everything in the middle (the right discarded sequence from the left half and the left discarded sequence from the right half) is larger than the maximum of the best subsequence of either half. We concatenate the sequences to compose the left and right discarded sequences, and the best sequences up to this stage. This is the result:

(defn best [myseq]
  (let [N (count myseq)]
    (case N
      1 {:l 0 :r 0 :sl [] :sr [] :seq myseq :sum (first myseq)}
      2 (if (and (> (first myseq) 0) (> (second myseq) 0))
          {:l 0 :r 0 :sl [] :seq myseq :sr [] :sum (apply + myseq)}
          (if (< (first myseq) (second myseq))
            {:l (first myseq) :r 0 :sl [(first myseq)] :sr [] :seq (rest myseq) :sum (second myseq)}
            {:l 0 :r (second myseq) :sl [] :sr (rest myseq) :seq [(first myseq)] :sum (first myseq)}))
      (let [n (Math/round (double (/ N 2)))
            m (- N n)
            s1 (take n myseq)
            s2 (reverse (take m (reverse myseq)))
            m1 (best s1)
            m2 (best s2)
            sum2 (+ (:sum m1) (:sum m2))
            cost (+ (:r m1) (:l m2))
            sumt (+ sum2 cost)
            ]
        (if (> sumt (max (:sum m1) (:sum m2)))
          {:l (:l m1) :r (:r m2) :sl (:sl m1) :sr (:sr m2) :seq (concat (:seq m1) (:sr m1) (:sl m2) (:seq m2)) :sum sumt}
          (if (> (:sum m1) (:sum m2))
            {:l (:l m1) :r (+ (:r m1) (:l m2) (:sum m2) (:r m2)) :sl (:sl m1) :sr (concat (:sr m1) (:sl m2) (:seq m2) (:sr m2)) :seq (:seq m1) :sum (:sum m1)}
            {:l (+ (:l m1) (:r m1) (:sum m1) (:l m2)) :r (:r m2) :sl (concat (:sl m1) (:seq m1) (:sr m1) (:sl m2)) :sr (:sr m2) :seq (:seq m2) :sum (:sum m2)}))
        ))
    ))

As test data, we choose three sequences, one whose best subsequence is in the middle, separated by negative numbers (one in this case), another whose best subsequence is at the left side, and it is not worth to join it with another positive sequence at the right side, and one whose best subsequence is itself.

(def ex-bestmiddle [-1 -3 -2 1 2 -1 3 -2 2 1 -1 -3])
(def ex-bestleft [-1 3 2 1 -2 -5 -3 -3 2 3 -1 -3])
(def ex-bestall [5 -3 -2 2 2 -1 3 -2 2 1 -1 3])

For the last one:

(best ex-bestall)

{:l 0, :r 0, :sl [], :sr [], :seq (5 -3 -2 2 2 -1 3 -2 2 1 -1 3), :sum 9}

For the best subsequence on the left side:

(best ex-bestleft)

{:l -1, :r -12, :sl [-1], :sr (-2 -5 -3 -3 2 3 -1 -3), :seq (3 2 1), :sum 6}

And for the best subsequence in the middle:

(best ex-bestmiddle)

{:l -6, :r -4, :sl (-1 -3 -2), :sr (-1 -3), :seq (1 2 -1 3 -2 2 1), :sum 6}

The code is on Github under ```src/main/clj```.

item.title: Manipulating SVG images from browser Javascript
item.description:
SVG files are vector images based on a XML specification for describing geometric shapes (vector images). The fact that the image itself is an XML element makes it an ideal candidate to be manipulated from our client-side code. Unfortunately, SVG elements are not entirely treated in the same way that HTML elements are. In particular, they hold an internal DOM.

I am working on a project that involves dealing with a chart produced by the D3.js library, which produces SVG images.

In particular, I could convert a collection of labels whose XML tag was "text" within the SVG image to a Javascript array in this way:

var labelArray = [].slice.call(document.getElementsByTagName("text"));

Then I used the Functional Javascript library, which is cool, to select the element I was looking for

var label = fjs.first(function(elem) {
                    // textContent is an attribute of SVG element type
                    return elem.textContent === "ad";
})(labelsArray);

And then set special properties on it, so it would be distinguishable from the rest of the elements:

label.style.fontSize = "20px";
label.style.fontWeight = "bold";

Otherwise, elements with specific ID could be accessed firstly by getting the SVG file content from the SVG DOM element first, then accessing the internal element by ID:

var a = document.getElementById("imagesvg");
a.addEventListener("load",function(){
            var svgDoc = a.contentDocument; //get the inner DOM of image.svg
            var delta = svgDoc.getElementById("delta"); //get the inner element by id
},false)

Notice that the file is called image.svg and that the browser can load it asynchronously, and that's the reason for the load event handler.

item.title: Installing Theano on Windows
item.description:
Since Theano team works under Linux, a non-trivial amount of hacking is required to get it working on Windows.

In this post I assume you are going with Cristoph Gohlke's packages (for reasons, read here)

Make sure you also have MS Visual C++ and the NVidia CUDA Toolkit. If you don't have it, add the Visual C++ cl.exe compiler's directory to the path. Mine was under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 10\VC\bin.

First think you need, after installing Theano, is the nose package, since Gohlke's build needs it at initialization time. Download it and install it from Gohlke's site along with Theano.

Next, you need this .theanorc to be put under your home directory under ```C:\USER\```

[global]device = gpu
[nvcc]compiler_bindir=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 10.0\VC\bin# flags=-m32 # we have this hard coded for now
[blas]ldflags =# ldflags = -lopenblas # placeholder for openblas support

I am not very sure how to use OpenBLAS from here. I assume that if all CPU operations are done via Numpy and SciPy, then their default BLAS routines are used, and no direct call to a third BLAS implementation is made, but who knows! (Well, I looked into it a little bit and it seems Theano calls BLAS directly, I guess you may want to install OpenBLAS).

OK, we have the NVidia compiler and tools, the MS compiler that nvcc needs and the configuration. The last thing we need is to install a GNU C and C++ compiler that supports 64 bit Windows binary creation. There is a project called MinGW-w64 that does that. I recommend to download a private build from the user rubenvb that does not come along with the Python environment embedded as the more official build does. Put the bin directory (where GCC is located) of that installation in the Path (Control panel, etc). Theano needs this to compile the symbolic operations to object code and then to CUDA kernels if applicable, I presume.

If you run into errors of type "GCC: sorry, unimplemented: 64-bit mode not compiled in", then your MinGW is not x86_64 compliant. The NVidia compiler nvcc can also complain if it finds no cl.exe in the path.

By the way, all of this was to use deep learning techniques for Kaggle competitions, so the intended consequence was to install PyLearn2. This is not listed under Gohlke's libraries, but it is not low level and all is based on Theano and maybe other numerical packages such as Numpy. Being a pure Python package, you need to clone it from Github:

git clone git://github.com/lisa-lab/pylearn2.git

And then perform

cd pylearn2
python setup.py install

There is an easier procedure that will not require you to manually perform the git operations, and it is through pip

pip install git+git://github.com/lisa-lab/pylearn2.git

You have pip under your Python installation, within the Scripts directory, in the case it came with Python, or if you got Gohlke's installer.

This will also leave the module correctly accessible through Python.

Pylearn2's tutorial test is a little bit complicated to be a "hello world" test, so I looked for another quick example to see if my installation was finished. A very nice one popped up in this link. But first I have to tell that this made me realize that Gohlke's Theano is missing three files, something very, very strange since they are called from within Theano. In particular, the module missing is everything under theano.compat. In this case, just copy the contents from Theano's Github repository directory compat to a compat directory created on your local theano installation under Python 2.7 (mine C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\theano).

After that, run the code in this link, which is a neural network solving the XOR problem. And we are done.

item.title: The Monty Hall problem (my explanation)
item.description:
If I tell you: There are 1K bitcoins 1 wallet that will be yours if you guess which wallet out of three is the right one, the rest containing an amount of zero bitcoins, and ask you to point out an initial selection, then showed you that, effectively, one of the remaining wallets contains zero bitcoins... and finally giving you the opportunity to change wallet. Would you change? The awnser is yes.

This is so because there is new evidence now that supports a higher probability that the remaining unseen wallet is the right choice, whereas there is none about your current choice. The fact that you selected wallet 1, and given that choice, I showed you wallet 2, that leaves wallet 3 with a posterior probability of 2/3. This does not happen for our current wallet 1, since choosing 1 influenced my decision to show you 2. More precisely: You chose wrongly with probability 2/3. With that probability, I show you the only possible door that I can, leaving the 2/3 for the remaining unseen and unchosen door. On the contrary, you choose well with 1/3 probability, but then I can choose among 2 doors to show you, each with a probability of 1/2. This is how we include my decision (or necessity) to show you 2 into the math (this is the best explanation you are gonna get from all over the internet): Let's call R "right choice" V "visible incorrect wallet" and S "your choice". We need to compute $P(R=3|V=2,S=1)$, the probability of 3 being the right wallet, after you selected 1 and I showed you that 2 was not right (remember that all priors are 1/3).

$$P(R=3|V=2,S=1)=$$ $$\quad\frac{P(V=2,S=1|R=3)P(R=3)}{P(V=2,S=1|R=3)P(R=3)+P(V=2,S=1|R=1)P(R=1)}=$$ $$\quad\frac{1\times 1/3}{1\times 1/3 + 1/2 \times 1/3}=2/3$$ $$P(V=2,S=1|R=3)=1$$

is the probability that, given R=3, then I was forced to show you the incorrect wallet remaining (you already chose one incorrect wallet). $$P(V=2,S=1|R=1)=1/2$$ because there are two possible incorrect wallets (since you selected the correct one) that I can choose from to show you.

Let's compute the same posterior for the case I decide not to change wallet: $$P(R=1|V=2,S=1)=$$ $$\quad\frac{P(V=2,S=1|R=1)P(R=1)}{P(V=2,S=1|R=3)P(R=3)+P(V=2,S=1|R=1)P(R=1)}$$ $$\quad\frac{1/2\times 1/3}{1\times 1/3 + 1/2 \times 1/3}=1/3$$

Therefore if you change you have more chances of winning the 1000 bitcoins.

Needless to say, this works for every possible combination of $R$, $S$ and $V$. This happens, as I mentioned, because of the way I was influenced (forced) to show you the incorrect remaining wallets. To see it intuitively, imagine 100 wallets, and that you chose one amongst them, and I am forced to show you 98 incorrect wallets, leaving your choice and another one. Is it more likely that this particular wallet is the correct one (that your choice forced me to leave it) or that you chose wisely amongst 100 wallets? If you choose 99 incorrect wallets, the set that I show you is the same, except for the chosen incorrect wallets each time, and will never contain the particular correct wallet.

There is a cool Android app in case you want to check how the law of large numbers works for this problem.

item.title: Powering up python as a data analysis platform
item.description:
When working with Machine Learning algorithms we face large data movement, but in many algorithms the most important part is a heavy use of linear algebra operations and other mathematical/vectorial computations.

Intel has a math library that is optimized for the latest processors (MKL), including programmer-made optimizations for multiple core counts, wider vector units and more varied architectures which yield a performance that could not be achieved only with compiler automated optimization for routines such as highly vectorized and threaded linear algebra, fast Fourier transforms, and vector math and Statistics. These functions are royalty-free, so including them statically in the program comes at no cost.

Cristoph Gohlke and collaborators have a MKL license and have taken the effort to compile a series of Python modules compiled agaist them. In particular, Numpy and Scipy include these powerful libraries. Add to this that he has already compiled the binaries for Windows 64 bits which are very rare on the internet.

The following are two tests with a positive definite matrix. We compute the eigenvalues in R and Python, using the symmetric eigenvalue solver in each case. The processor is a i5 3210M not plugged in to the socket (losing approx. half its performance). Note that this version of R is compiled against standard Atlas libraries.

B=read.csv("B.csv",header=F)
st=proc.time(); eigB=eigen(B,symmetric=T); en=proc.time()
> en-st
   user  system elapsed
   0.58    0.00    0.58

In Python:

from time import time
import numpy
B=numpy.loadtxt("B.csv", delimiter=",")
st = time(); U, E = numpy.linalg.eigh(B); en = time()
>>> en-st
0.13400006294250488

A final remark is that there exists an opensource alternative to high-performance CPU computing, and it is the OpenBLAS libraries. Their performance is comparable to MKL.

Link to the positive definite matrix used in the experiments here. Link to Christoph Gohlke's page here.

Despite the fact that I've been aware of Scikits Learn (sklearn) for some time during my postgraduate years, I never got the chance to really use Python for data analysis and, instead, I had been a victim of my own inertia and limited myself to use R and especially Matlab.

I must say, in the beginning, Python looks awkward: it was inconceivable for me to use an invisible element (spaces or tabs) as a structural construction of a program (defining blocks), in a way much similar to Fortran, which I always considered weird (coming from the C world). This and the lack of the omnipresent, C-syntax end-of-line semicolon, prove to be a major boosting element when programming in Python. I must say that whatever lack in computer performance is overcome by the speed the programmer experiences when writing the software. This applies to general software, such as the App server that I am preparing, which is being written in Python using the Google App Engine, and I have to say that it just runs smoothly, no need for recompilations, clear syntax and one-line complex data-processing pieces of code.

Regarding data analysis, it is a little more complicated than Matlab's clear orientation towards numerical linear algebra (where everything is a Matrix). Good comparisons and reasons supporting my view are

  • https://sites.google.com/site/pythonforscientists/python-vs-matlab
  • http://www.stat.washington.edu/~hoytak/blog/whypython.html
  • http://stevetjoa.com/305/

Now, going to Machine Learning specifics, sklearn has everything you need for the majority of the work a machine learning practitioner will ever need.

  • Data preprocessors, including text vectorizers and TF IDF preprocessors
  • SVM implementations
  • Stochastic Gradient Descent algorithms for fast regression and classification
  • Random Forest and other ensemble methods for robust regression and classification
  • Clustering algorithms
  • Data dimensionality reduction algorithms such as LLE, ISOMAP and spectral embeddings
  • Results presentation, including mean squared error for regression and precision/recall tables for classification. It even computes the area under the ROC curve.

This, added to the clean, standardized and well-designed interface, which always has a .fit method for every object which performs the task of learning from samples, and then either a .transform method if the learning is unsupervised (such as LLE, ISOMAP, ICA, PCA, or the preprocessors, etc) or .predict if the learning is supervised (SVM, SGD, ensemble...). If enables a pipelining mechanism that allows us to build the whole pipeline from data reading to results output.

One of the lead programmers of the project, Andreas Mller has a very insightful blog.

I decided to be more active on Kaggle. For the moment I scored 13th on the Leaderboard of the Amazon employee access competition that recently opened.

Last but not least, just to comment that future work seems to be bent on using the GPU to perform all the linear algebra. Check out

  • Gnumpy
  • Deep Belief Networks
  • PyCUDA

item.title: Image pan-sharpening with PCA
item.description:
There is a collection of methods that are denominated image pan-sharpening, since they use information available in multiple bands to create an image output that enjoys properties from all sources, while minimizing drawbacks. The sources combined will contain several frequency bands, maybe hundreds or thousands. In this case, we are interested in combining a source with a high resolution but in gray scale, and a RGB image.

This is especially important in satellite imagery, since satellites often incorporate a multispectral camera with limited resolution and a high-resolution, low-band/grayscale camera among their equipment.

To play with this, we will use Matlab (since I've worked a little bit with its image functions and array transformations, and this job will be quick)

Data preparation

We first load original image (included in Matlab)

peppers = imread('peppers.png');

Now we simulate uniband (grayscale) and multiband (downscaled) imagery

multiband = imresize(peppers, 0.25);
uniband = rgb2gray(peppers);

The multiband image looks like this

And the high resolution (low band) image looks like this

In the first case, we resize the image to a quarter of its size ***in both dimensions***. This means we loose 15/16 of the information! In the second case we compute a grayscale image, loosing complementary information.

These two images are the ones we are interested in combining.

Image pan-sharp with PCA

We still need to prepare the data one more time. We need to upscale multiband image (again, color image and same size than original but with the information from the downscaled version) so that we can combine it with the hight resolution image (adjust its dimensions)

interpolated=imresize(multiband,[size(uniband,1) size(uniband,2)]);

{% img center /images/interpolated.png 'Interpolated image from the low resolution, hight band image' 'images' %}

The missing information from this image with respect to the original is noticeable to the eye in form of blur.

We will now perform PCA on the images. To do that we need to convert the images to the relevant variables we want to consider in the analysis. In this case, we want to extract the bands of the images, so that we linearize the images, thus turning matrices into unidimensional vectors. In case of the grayscale image, this is easily done by just using the ```(:)``` operator. Bit in case of the RGB image, we will need to reshape into a three-dimensional multivariate X = (R, G, B)

X=double(reshape(interpolated,numel(interpolated)/3,3));

where we have also converted the data type to double so that we can use Matlab functions.

Now we can compute the components and the projections onto the PCA space

[C,Y]=pca(X);

where ```C``` is the matrix of loadings and ```Y``` is the projections of the data onto the PCA space.

At this point, out of curiosity, we can compute correlations. Notice that the first projection will correlate a lot with the univariate, since both capture mean luminosity levels, which is an indicator of which component can be substituted by the higher resolution grayscale image.

corrcoef(Y(:,1),double(uniband(:)))
corrcoef(Y(:,2),double(uniband(:)))
corrcoef(Y(:,3),double(uniband(:)))

The first one yields around ```0.98```. Substitute the component now

Z=Y;
Z(:,1)=(double(uniband(:)-min(uniband(:)))./double(max(uniband(:))-min(uniband(:))))*(max(Y(:,1))-min(Y(:,1)))+min(Y(:,1));

We are adapting the maximum and minimum luminosity of the grayscale image to match that of the first component.

We now project the new components back to the original RGB space. The matrix ```C``` is not orthonormal, so that we don't get a properly scaled representation, so we do it manually (we could also make the matrix ```C``` orthonormal, though the effect of changing the first component would have impacted the final luminosity levels and thus we still would have needed to rescale the colors)

G=Z*C';
I = (G - min(G(:)))/(max(G(:))-min(G(:)));

Lastly we reshape from (R, G, B) multivariate to an RGB image

merged = reshape(I, size(interpolated));

The result shows that, effectively, we enjoy the best part of the two worlds

As mentioned, we could play with the luminiscence levels to attain a color more loyal to the original.

The reason why this works is that the first PCA component takes most of the information, thus creating a sort of best fit for all colors in the RGB spectrum. This is a kind of luminiscence, which is what the grayscape image is and what we substitute it by.

Donwload full Matlab program form Github

item.title: Google's original Page Rank implementation
item.description:
Ever since I took a good course on Matrix Analysis, I have been curious about how Google's Page Rank algorithm was related to Matrix theory, because I never got a chance to have a look at it when I studied computer systems.

Imagine the graph of web pages visited by Google crawlers, where $\mathbf{M}$ is the adjacency matrix with the outgoing links in the columns, where each edge in the web page $i$ pointing to a web page $j$ (which can be the same) has a score of $\frac{1}{n_i}$, where $n_i$ is the number of outgoing links in the webpage $i$. This matrix might present a number of problems with actual graphs, so what Google did was to include page self references and random jumps between pages with a small pfrobability given by a parameter $\beta$.

$$ \mathbf{G} = \beta \mathbf{M} + (1-\beta) \frac{\mathbf{1} \mathbf{1}^ T}{N} $$

where $N$ is the total number of web pages in the system and $\mathbf{1}$ is the vector of all ones of size $N$.

$\mathbf{G}$, being a stochastic matrix, has one as the largest eigenvalue (in module). This can be proved by taking $\mathbf{G}^ T \mathbf{1}=\mathbf{1}$, and since $\mathbf{G}^ T = (\mathbf{P}^ {-1})^ {-T} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{P}^ {-T}$, where $\mathbf{P}$ diagonalizes $\mathbf{G}$ and $\mathbf{D}$ is the resulting diagonal matrix with the eigenvalues of both $\mathbf{G}$ and $\mathbf{G^ {T}}$. Thus one is also the largest eigenvalue of $\mathbf{G}$. Proving that this is in fact the largest can be done by applyting the Gershgoring circle theorem.

Intuitively, applyting $$\mathbf{G}$$ several times has the effect of building a power matrix $\mathbf{G}^ M$ whose largest eigenvalue is also one, but the rest are the power of elements less than one, meaning that each power decreases all the eigenvalues except the first one. This has the effect of minimizing the component of any vector (the projection) in the subspace spanned by the eigenvector corresponding to any eigenvalue except the first one. Eventually, all of them reach zero, leaving only the component of the original vector in the subspace of the eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue. This means $\mathbf{G}^ M \mathbf{x} \rightarrow \mathbf{w}$, as $M$ tends to infinite, where $\mathbf{w}$ is the dominant eigenvector (the one corresponding to the eigenvalue one).

The elements of this vectors are the important for all the pages registered on the database by the crawlers or robots.

Obviously this demands a lot of computation since the web is ever changing and this power method would need to be performed in batch intermitently, so efficient implementations are needed (based on Map Reduce or not).

item.title: My Git workflow
item.description:
In the past I had used CVS as most of the people. Git is much powerful, in so many levels. For starters, you never, NEVER lose files. You can always go back to a previous version, the soft ware, or the hard. But Git requires a little more attention on the part of the user than other control version systems. This starts by fixing the basic concepts clearly.

Concepts

The concepts, from basic qto more complex, and also sorted by the first time you are likely to come across them, is:

  • Tracked file: A file that is under version control. You specifically told Git to track it at some point of its life.
  • Woring directory: This is the classical concept, your working copy of the project, including the files you modify, the ones that are tracked and others that you want to leave untracked (such as IDE files or personal notes).
  • Local repository: This is the Git repository stored on your local computer. It is not your local working directory, but the files stored in the ```.git``` directory within your working copy.
  • remote: A remote is a remote Git server that stores our project. Several remotes can exist for a project and we always need to specify the remote to which we are going to send our changes.
  • Remote repository: The remote repository that stores the version of the project that everybody can see.
  • Branch: This is the usual concept of branch. Branches of the project may evolve in an independent way from each other. All commits are attached to a branch. Local branches may not exist in the remote repository and remote branches may have not been updated in your local repository at some point. The default branch is called master.
  • Conflict: Incompatible changes from a source were incorporated to a dirty copy (meaning that you modify something that had been already modified), or you have a commit that modifies something already modified in the source you are applying. You will need to resolve this by hand.
  • stash: Shelve your local changes. In other words, pack your dirty working copy and leave a clean working directory that matches the contents of your local repository. This is important if you want to do operations on files that you have changed on your working copy, since Git will complain otherwise.
  • unstash: Get the changes from the stash into your local copy, making it dirty if it was not. If it was not dirty or you got changes from another branch or from the remote repository, you are likely to have conflicts and will need to resolve them.
  • pull: Update remote changes in your local repository (and your working copy so you can see them). If you have a dirty working copy you will need to stash your local changes.
  • Dirty local copy: Tracked files in the working directory that have been changed.
  • commit: A change in a tracked file (dirty local copy) that gets added to the local repository. You commit to a branch.
  • push: The commits (local changes that now form part of your local repository) get sent to the remote repository so that everybody can finally access them. This updates the remote branch.
  • merge: This happens when two members have changed the same tracked files on a branch in the the remote repository. The last user in pushing the changes (B) will need to pull the changes that the first one (A) already pushed, so that the official history was written firstly by A. The conflicts will most likely need to be resolved by hand by B, since Git does not understand any particular language (and is not intelligent to decide on the conflicts or have criteria to do so). Once merged, B ends up with a dirty working copy, that he needs to commit and then push. This last push will be accepted by the remote repository server (if no one has put new stuff in the meantime).
  • rebase: This is a especially useful type of merge in which a user has not pulled down changes for a while and there are a number of commits in the remote repository. If the user commits, then he can rebase the remote branch onto his, so that his commit is merged on top of the remote commits. The user can then push to the remote branch and see his changes reflected there. The rebase command is very versatile since it allows us to modify previous commits in our repository.
  • reset: Set your branch to any commit in your repository. At this point a VERY IMPORTANT NOTE must be mentioned: any repository, including the local one, stores commits. This means that commits ALWAYS survive, they are always present, and one can always reset a branch head to a particular commit if the commit hash is available. It does not matter that the commit had been "lost" in the branch chain.
  • cherry-pick: One can also cherry-pick a commit in the repository, given its hash, from any branch and apply it to any other branch. Again, it does not matter that the picked commit does not currently appear on any branch, it suffices for it to have been stored in the repository at some point.
  • log: This command is useful since it shows the chain of commits we have on our local repository that end up in our current state. This does not show all the commits that once belonged to a branch if the branch was reset and then new commits arrived (in a similar way to when we undo something in MS Word and then write new stuff, we cannot redo). Useful for rebasing stuff.
  • reflog: This is ALL the repository history, including committed stuff, branch changes, pulled changes, etc. You can find EVERYTHING here, even commits that were apparently "lost" from a branch. If you feel you have lost a commit, just issue ```git reflog``` and cherry-pick from there.

My workflow

When you are developing a new feature for your project, want you want to do is branch the master branch (or any other, but it makes sense to pick up the official state of the project and start from there).

git checkout -b newfeature

This creates a local branch. We are interested in storing our changes remotely so that if something happens to our local copy (major Git messup that is easy to just ignore and pull the remote, hard drive issues, computer issues, get your stuff done in some other computer, etc), we have our changes in the remote server too.

git push origin newfeature
git branch --set-origin=origin/newfeature

This creates the remote branch and sets the default link to our local branch, so that we can push to it.

After this, we can do our changes. I normally spend some time with a feature and by the time I want to commit to master (when the changes are not enough to be peer reviewed in a pull request to the master branch), some other workmate has committed something, which forces me to pull and rebase.

Imagine that I am working on newfeature and I notice that master has changed. It is better to incorporate the remote changes sooner so that conflicts are minimal. I first stash my local changes, since I will need to change branch to pull master (you can do it from newfeature branch, but I like it this way).

git stash
git checkout master
git pull

Now we have the remote latest changes. We switch to the newfeature branch

git checkout newfeature
git rebase -i master

This tells git to get (local, which was just updated) commits onto the current branch, newfeature. Now newfeature is updated with the latest master state. We can keep on working. Get our latest changes, the ones we stashed.

git stash apply

This applies the top of the stash to the current clean local branch, and does not remove them from the stash. I am normally interested in keeping these changes just in case. I can later remove them with ```git stash drop```. I sometimes use ```git stash pop``` which applies changes and removes them from the stash. If I need to refer to the stash to get a change that I know was there but am not sure it is on the top, then I use ```git stash show –name-only```, which gives me the names of the changed files.

When I feel I can commit (because I am done or because I want to store remotely)

git commit -m "Message"
git push origin newfeature

Which saves my commits in the remote branch (remote repository).

I sometimes need to modify something that I committed, because I forgot to include it (and we want our master history to be clean of mistakes and easy to follow), I prepare my local changes (tracked files) for commit fixup. First I use the ```git add``` command to add these files to the subsequent commit. This commit will be done in a special manner: using the ```–fixup=``` modifier, which accepts the hash of the commit to be modified. This is an extremely versatile modifier, since it allows us to modify commits buried deep beneath our current head. This creates a new commit chain with the fixed commit and all the commits that followed it, with new versions adapted to the changes we have introduced (and of course, all with new hashes, since they are all new commits).

I came across a very easy command pipe to do this, since adding files one by one is a time waster:

git status | grep modified | cut -d: -f2 | xargs git add

The command ```status``` gives us the modified files, among other stuff (untracked files, etc). I filter the modified files (getting only the file name) and then add them as an argument to ```git add```.

We now fix the particular commit. In this case, I get the commit hash with ```git log```.

git commit --fixup=24ee1df941679953529aabc3d0eef5727a44c094

This creates a new commit on top of the rest. We need to squash everything so that git creates the new commit chain, wich entirely different commits and with the fixing and fixed commits merged into one. If the commit is buried below the head, you would use the commit previous to the one being fixed. Imagine this chain

c0cf52f4a914641efdc635bbc6195b6bef084cdc Categories and other plugin stuff
021086446698443ee57858872e14e7ee8ca9e2e5 Remove deploy stuff that got added by mistake
24ee1df941679953529aabc3d0eef5727a44c094 First commit to my-source
7f49807d5c5651baccb6d66c504549713a7ae7d7 Site updated at 2015-01-05 15:12:45 UTC

When you create the fixup commit, it will appear on top of the chain

f36806a856994c8365e199a72501a5461ca99497 fixup! First commit to my-source
c0cf52f4a914641efdc635bbc6195b6bef084cdc Categories and other plugin stuff
021086446698443ee57858872e14e7ee8ca9e2e5 Remove deploy stuff that got added by mistake
24ee1df941679953529aabc3d0eef5727a44c094 First commit to my-source
7f49807d5c5651baccb6d66c504549713a7ae7d7 Site updated at 2015-01-05 15:12:45 UTC

Then you autosquash the chain, selecting the commit previous to the fix

git rebase -i --autosquash 7f49807d5c5651baccb6d66c504549713a7ae7d7

The result is a new chain

c927d675189eedd89d972663e2ef0ffe1438f4f7 Categories and other plugin stuff
e08ef8e27b3fd3c15e07a5e032e66a67a533ca3d Remove deploy stuff that got added by mistake
7d94aace9629272848382abfc217282c676f108e First commit to my-source
7f49807d5c5651baccb6d66c504549713a7ae7d7 Site updated at 2015-01-05 15:12:45 UTC

Where the new ```7d94aace9629272848382abfc217282c676f108e``` contains the modifications needed.

In case the commit we want to fix is on top of the chain, the autosquash is simpler:

git rebase -i --autosquash HEAD~2

If I had pushed my branch to the remote repository, then I would have to force push, since there is no way my local branch and the remote one are compatible. To do that, you need to be pretty sure nobody is in the process of committing anything to that particular branch (this is not a problem if you are working on this feature on your own), and issue

git push origin newfeature -f

Where origin is my remote repository name and ```-f``` overwrites the remote contents.

Final thoughts
